author: Christopher Fritz
message:
This update took me by surprise. I work with large photos of census images, and it's convenient for me to have the mouse over the lower scrollbar and just reach over and scroll to move from left to right without losing my focus on another application I'm transcribing data in. Are there any plans to re-implement mouse-wheel scrolling without the scroll bars? (Maybe shift+scroll for side-to-side scrolling?) Not intending this as a feature request, but rather just curious as to whether it's being considered. For my census transcribing, I'll probably just adjust to alt-tab, arrow key, alt-tab back. Not a big deal there.

What I'm really wonder is whether there will be a way to visually remove the "bird-eye view" square. Should I submit a bug requesting an option to disable this?

Hopefully I don't sound like I'm complaining. I absolutely love Gwenview, and the removal of scrollbars I feel is a very strong visual improvement when viewing images larger than the screen.

replies.message: Mouse wheel scrolling is back in 4.8.1, not sure how I managed to miss this! I have no plan to add an option to hide the bird-eye view for now: it is the only way to know where you are in the image, now that the scrollbars are gone.

author: Banifou
message:
Gwenview is amazing! I'm using it for many years now.
Actually I'm stunning about the resize method! When I save a JPG file using resize method (without changing anything!) the file size is mostly tremendously reduced, without any noticeable loss of quality. This can not be achieved with batch resize, unfortunately!
This method is very important for me because I need to handle a large bunch of images, they need to be small sized (for an internet shop). I tried Imagemagick and Gimp but couldn't achieve the performance of Gwenview.

What is the algorithm? Is there a way to use it in batch mode?

Salut

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: Gwenview relies on Qt JPEG support to save JPEG files. What probably happens is your image contains extra information (for example large thumbnails set by the digital camera) which got dropped at save time. A tool like jhead (with the -purejpg option) can help you produce smaller jpegs.

author: Falk
message:
I'd hoped the png size bug would be gone with 4.8.1 as it seems like an easy fix to do, but it's still there. So I guess it's harder than than it looks.
Is there some way to help track this bug down? It's become a real annoyance as I have a load of photos as png in 2560x1920 size and Gwenview won't show any of them except as thumbnails.
So I'd really like to see this fixed soon.

(Sorry for writing here, but bugs.kde.org isn't working for me at the moment.)

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: I haven't spent much time on Gwenview this month and haven't been able to reproduce the bug so far, making it difficult (read: impossible) to fix. What makes you think it is an easy fix? Do you have any idea how to fix it?

replies.author: Falk
replies.message:
I don't have an idea (yet) what causes it and how to fix it.
My (possibly wrong) assumption is based on the fact that the bug only occurs with png images of specific sizes and there are probably not that many places in Gwenview that depend specifically on an image's size and user configuration at the same time, as this bug is user-specific too.
My attempts at isolating the part of KDE's config which causes this have sadly not been successful up to now. So I'd hoped you have an idea of how to triage this in a better way or some pointers as to what to look at or what to try to help you find the cause.

Also, the bugtracker seems to have recovered, here is the link: https://bugs.kde.org/show_b... I also posted a tiny example image there to fiddle with.

Still, the selectiveness of this bug puzzles me. Does Gwenview load images in fixed-size chunks and at some sizes there may a one-off error in how many chunks to allocate or display? But this would need to be user-config specific as well as it won't occur for every user on the same machine…

Someone suggested to try to set up a qemu image that can reproduce this bug. If I manage to do this I'll send it to you so you can do more proper tests.

author: Berend Dekens (@cyberwizzard)
message:
Is it possible to either reimplement a scrollbar or improve the birdseye overview for extremely wide images? I am using Gwenview to watch PNG plots from GNUplot of waveforms of our radio receivers.

For example I have images that are 32660x1000 pixels and the overview is bigger than the screen making it impossible to quickly jump to every part.

Also, is it a design choice to limit the width of an image to 32k? I thought that I was able to use plots up to 80.000 pixels width in older versions...

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
The bird eye view is indeed a bit painful for wide images, I am not sure how to improve it however. You should nevertheless be able to quickly scroll through images with the arrow keys (using shift to make scrolling faster).

Regarding limitation to 32k, there is no such limitation in Gwenview, but there may be one in Qt.
